summary: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York today announced criminal charges against three Albany men for their roles in a February 2010 shooting that left LeSheldon Stanford dead.  The SEC's complaint alleges that Shanard Smith, Anthony Hawkins, and Shuntavious Seay engaged in a series of aggressive actions in the early morning hours of February 14, 2010, that resulted in the death of Stanford.  According to the complaint, Smith and Seay were among a large group of people who confronted Stanford inside the club, including members of the East Mafia Family, who were affiliated with EMF.  As alleged in the SEC's Complaint, Smith, Hawkins, Seay, and a security guard were among the people who kicked Stanford out of the club and into the parking lot.  In a parallel action, the United States Attorney’s Office for New York filed criminal charges on two of the defendants.  On February 21, 2020, the SEC filed a civil injunctive action against Smith and Hawkins, charging them with violating the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b) of Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and Section 17-a-3 thereunder.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the complaint or the SEC, Smith has consented to the entry of a final judgment that permanently enjoins him from violating the charged provisions of the federal securities laws, orders him to pay disgorgement of ill-gotten gains plus prejudgment interest, and bars him from serving as an officer or director of a public company.  Hawkins has also agreed to pay a civil penalty of $10,000.  Seay has agreed to settle the SEC case by consenting to a settlement that is subject to court approval.  For further information, see Litigation Release No. 17-8-4 (a) (b) (3) (B) (2014).  The complaint also names Antonio Seay as a defendant in the case, and Hawkins as a co-defendant in violation of Section 24-7-703 of the Exchange Act.  To learn more about how to spot a pattern of misconduct in the criminal justice system, see Criminal Justice Reform Bulletin No. 24-6-7 (a).  In addition, the complaint charges Hawkins with violating Section 16-5-1 (c) and with aiding and abetting violations of Rule 16-4-3 (b).  Hawkins and Seays have agreed to be permanently enjoined from participating in the issuance, purchase, offer, or sale of any firearm in connection with the alleged conduct of the three officers.
